# A Appendix
## A. 1 Convergence for the DMD algorithm: proof of Theorem 3.1

Step 1: On the convergence of $\left(y^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$.
In order to study the convergence of the sequence $\left(y^{k}\right)_{k \geq 0}$ towards the unique minimizer $y^{\star}$ of $\Gamma_{g}$, we recall that Lemma 2.1 in [35] (combined with (3.2)) guarantees that

$$
D_{F}\left(w, \mathrm{P}_{u}^{m}(v)\right) \leq D_{F}(w, u)+\langle v, w-u\rangle+m \frac{\|v\|_{\infty}^{2}}{2}
$$

for any $w, u \in\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{0}\right)^{d} \cap B_{m}, v \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Selecting $v=\gamma_{k+1} \kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k}\right), u=y^{k}$ and $w=y^{\star}$ in the above inequality, and taking $m \geq\left\|y^{\star}\right\|_{1}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{k+1}\right) \leq & D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{k}\right)-\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k}\right), y^{k}-y^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& +m \gamma_{k+1}^{2} \frac{\left\|\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k}\right)\right\|_{\infty}^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Assuming that the learning rate satisfies $\sum_{k \geq 1} \gamma_{k}^{2}<\infty$ and recalling (3.1), the Robbins-Siegmund theorem yields

$$
D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{n}\right) \xrightarrow{n \rightarrow \infty} D_{\infty}<\infty \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{k \geq 0} \gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k}\right), y^{k}-y^{\star}\right\rangle<\infty
$$

Since $\sum_{k \geq 1} \gamma_{k}=\infty$, we deduce that $\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{n}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{n}\right), y^{n}-y^{\star}\right\rangle=0$. The boundedness of the sequence $\left(y^{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$ guarantees the existence of a subsequence $(\varphi(n))_{n \geq 0}$ such that

$$
y^{\varphi(n)} \rightarrow y^{\infty} \in\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)^{d} \cap B_{m}, \quad \text { and } \quad\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{\varphi(n)}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\varphi(n)}\right), y^{\varphi(n)}-y^{\star}\right\rangle=0
$$

By continuity of $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{d} \ni y \mapsto \kappa(y) \nabla \Gamma_{g}(y)$, it follows that $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{\varphi(n)}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\varphi(n)}\right), y^{\varphi(n)}-\right.$ $\left.y^{\star}\right\rangle=\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{\infty}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\infty}\right), y^{\infty}-y^{\star}\right\rangle=0$ which in turn, by Lemma 3.1, implies that $y^{\infty}=y^{\star}$.

Coming back to (A.3), we eventually deduce that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{n}\right)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{\varphi(n)}\right)=0
$$

which clearly implies that $\left(y^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$ converges towards $y^{\star}$.
Step 2: On the convergence rate of $\left(\bar{y}^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$.
In order to derive the corresponding convergence rate, we come back to (A.2) and write

$$
\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k}\right), y^{k}-y^{\star}\right\rangle \leq D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{k}\right)-D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{k+1}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m \gamma_{k+1}^{2} M_{\star}^{2}
$$

Summing over $k=0, \cdots, n-1$ the previous inequality and recalling that $D_{F}\left(y^{k+1}, y^{\star}\right) \geq 0$, we get

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}\left\langle\kappa\left(y^{k-1}\right) \nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k-1}\right), y^{k-1}-y^{\star}\right\rangle \leq D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m M_{\star}^{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}^{2}
$$

By convexity of $\Gamma_{g}$ and Jensen's inequality, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k} \kappa\left(y^{k-1}\right)\left\langle\nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k-1}\right), y^{k-1}-y^{\star}\right\rangle & \geq\left(\min _{0 \leq k \leq n-1} y^{k} \wedge 1\right) \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}\left\langle\nabla \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k-1}\right), y^{k-1}-y^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& \geq\left(\min _{0 \leq k \leq n-1} y^{k} \wedge 1\right) \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}\left(\Gamma_{g}\left(y^{k-1}\right)-\Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\star}\right)\right) \\
& \geq\left(\min _{0 \leq k \leq n-1} y^{k} \wedge 1\right)\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}\right)\left(\Gamma_{g}\left(\bar{y}^{n}\right)-\Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\star}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

recalling that $\left(\bar{y}^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$ is the averaged version of $\left(y^{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$. Combining the two previous inequalities eventually yields

$$
\Gamma_{g}\left(\bar{y}^{n}\right)-\Gamma_{g}\left(y^{\star}\right) \leq \frac{D_{F}\left(y^{\star}, y^{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m M_{\star}^{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}^{2}}{\left(\min _{0 \leq k \leq n-1} y^{k} \wedge 1\right) \sum_{k=1}^{n} \gamma_{k}}, \quad n \geq 1
$$

which concludes the proof.

# A. 2 Proof of Proposition 3.1 

Step 1: The regularity and integrability conditions combined with the dominated convergence theorem guarantee that $h$ is continuously differentiable on $\mathbb{R} \times\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{0}\right)^{d}$. The expression for the derivatives $\partial_{\xi} h(\xi, y)$ and $\partial_{y_{i}} h(\xi, y), i=1, \cdots, d$, is easily obtained by differentiating under expectation. The convexity of $h$ then guarantees that $\operatorname{Argmin} h=\{\nabla h=0\}$.
Step 2: We here prove that the map $\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{0}\right)^{d} \ni y \mapsto g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right)$ defined by (3.6) is continuously differentiable with a derivative given by $\nabla\left(g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right)\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L\left(\xi^{\star}(y),-\langle y, X\rangle\right)\right]$. Let $y, h \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Note that the minimizers $\xi^{\star}(y+h), \xi^{\star}(y)$ of $\mathbb{E}[L(.,-\langle(y+h), X\rangle)]$ and $\mathbb{E}[L(.,-\langle y, X\rangle)]$ respectively, satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
g\left(r_{\rho}(y+h)\right) & -g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y+h),-\langle(y+h), X\rangle\right)\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y),-\langle y, X\rangle\right)\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y),-\langle(y+h), X\rangle\right)\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y),-\langle y, X\rangle\right)\right] \\
& =\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y)}, h\right\rangle+o(\|h\|)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\|h\| \downarrow 0$. Similarly, one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
& g\left(r_{\rho}(y+h)\right)-g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right) \\
& \geq \mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y+h),-\langle(y+h), X\rangle\right)\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\xi^{\star}(y+h),-\langle y, X\rangle\right)\right] \\
& =\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}, h\right\rangle \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{1}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle(y+t h), X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}-\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}, h\right\rangle d t \\
& =\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y)}, h\right\rangle \\
& \quad+\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}-\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y)}, h\right\rangle \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{1}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle(y+t h), X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}-\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}, h\right\rangle d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Our aim now is to prove that the two last terms appearing in the right-hand side of the above inequality are $o(\|h\|)$. Clearly, it suffices to prove that

$$
\lim _{h \downarrow 0} \mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y+h)}=\mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]_{\xi=\xi^{\star}(y)}
$$

and that

$$
\lim _{h \downarrow 0} \mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle(y+t h), X\rangle)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]
$$

locally uniformly in $\xi$.
Note that the convexity of the maps $\xi \mapsto \mathbb{E}[L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)]$, and $\xi \mapsto \mathbb{E}[L(\xi,-\langle(y+$ $h), X\rangle)]$ yields $\left(\xi-\xi^{*}(y)\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]>0$ for any $\xi \neq \xi^{*}(y)$ and $\left(\xi-\xi^{*}(y+\right.$ $h)\left) \mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} L(\xi,-\langle(y+h), X\rangle)\right]>0$ for any $\xi \neq \xi^{*}(y+h)$. Moreover, the continuity of $\mathbb{R} \times\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{0}\right)^{d} \ni(\xi, y) \mapsto \mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]$ guarantees that for any fixed $y$, $\xi \mapsto \mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} L(\xi,-\langle(y+h), X\rangle)\right]$ converges to $\xi \mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]$ as $h \downarrow 0$ locally uniformly. Now, [25, Theorem 2.6] guarantees that $\xi^{*}(y+h) \rightarrow \xi^{*}(y)$ as $\|h\| \downarrow 0$ which combined with the continuity of $\xi \mapsto \mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]$ implies (A.4).

The second point (A.5) is a consequence of the continuity of $\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \ni(\xi, y) \mapsto$ $\mathbb{E}\left[X \partial_{x} L(\xi,-\langle y, X\rangle)\right]$.

Combining the above arguments, we conclude that $y \mapsto g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right)$ is continuously differentiable and satisfies $\nabla\left(g\left(r_{\rho}(y)\right)\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[-X \partial_{x} L\left(\xi^{*}(y),-\langle y, X\rangle\right)\right]$.
Step 3: If $\left(\xi^{*}, y^{*}\right) \in \operatorname{Argmin} h$, then $\partial_{y_{i}} h\left(\xi^{*}, y^{*}\right)=0, i=1, \cdots, d$, which, according to the conclusion of the previous step, implies that

$$
\partial_{y_{i}} \Gamma_{g}\left(y^{*}\right)=\partial_{y_{i}}\left(g\left(r_{\rho}\left(y^{*}\right)\right)\right)-\frac{b_{i}}{y_{i}^{*}}=0, \quad i=1, \cdots, d
$$

Hence, $y^{*}$ is the unique minimizer of $\Gamma_{g}$. The proof is now complete.

# A. 3 Convergence of the SMD algorithm: proof of Theorem 3.2 

Step 1: On the convergence of $\left(z^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$
We use the inequality (A.1) with $G$ instead of $F$ (noting (3.8)) namely

$$
D_{G}\left(z, \mathrm{P}_{z^{\prime}}^{m}(v)\right) \leq D_{G}\left(z, z^{\prime}\right)+\left\langle v, z-z^{\prime}\right\rangle+m \vee 1\|v\|_{\infty}^{2}
$$

with $v=\gamma_{k+1}\left(\partial_{\xi} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right), \kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla_{y} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right)\right)^{T}, z^{\prime}=z^{k}$ and $z=z^{*}$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{G}\left(z^{*}, z^{k+1}\right) \leq & D_{G}\left(z^{*}, z^{k}\right)-\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\begin{array}{c}
\partial_{\xi} H(z, X) \\
\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)
\end{array}\right)\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, z^{k}-z^{*}\right\rangle \\
& -\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\Delta^{k+1}, z^{k}-z^{*}\right\rangle+m \vee 1 \gamma_{k+1}^{2} Y_{k+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the fact that $X^{k+1}$ is independent of $\left(z^{j}\right)_{0 \leq j \leq k}$ and introduced the notations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta^{k+1}=\binom{\partial_{\xi} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right)}{\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla_{y} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right)}-\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, \\
& Y_{k+1}:=\left\|\binom{\partial_{\xi} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right)}{\kappa\left(y^{k}\right) \nabla_{y} H\left(z^{k}, X^{k+1}\right)}\right\|_{\infty}^{2} . \\
& k \geq 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that since $z^{k}$ is $\mathcal{F}_{k}$-measurable and $X^{k+1}$ is independent of $\mathcal{F}_{k},\left(\Delta^{k}\right)_{k \geq 1}$ is a sequence of $\mathcal{F}$-martingale increments

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta^{k+1}\left|\mathcal{F}_{k}\right]=0, \quad \text { for } k \geq 0\right.
$$

Now, the previous identity together with (A.6) and observing that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{k+1} \mid \mathcal{F}_{k}\right] \leq N_{\star}^{2}:=\sup _{(\xi, y) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}_{+}^{d} \cap B_{m})} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\right]<\infty, \quad k \geq 0
$$

yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{k+1}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{k}\right] \leq & D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{k}\right)-\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& +m \vee 1 N_{\star}^{2} \gamma_{k+1}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The Robbins-Siegmund theorem guarantees that

$$
D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{n}\right) \stackrel{n \rightarrow \infty}{=} D_{\infty} \in L^{1}(\mathbb{P}) \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

and

$$
\sum_{n \geq 0} \gamma_{n+1}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{n}}, z^{n}-z^{\star}\right\rangle<\infty, \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

The first assertion above implies that the sequence $\left(z^{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$ is bounded while the second together with Lemma 3.2 and the condition $\sum_{k \geq 1} \gamma_{k}=\infty$ guarantees that

$$
\lim \inf _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{n}}, z^{n}-z^{\star}\right\rangle=0
$$

As a consequence, we may assume the existence of a subsequence $(\varphi(n))_{n \geq 0}$ such that

$$
z^{\varphi(n)} \rightarrow z^{\infty} \in \mathbb{R} \times\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}^{d} \cap B_{m}^{d}\right)
$$

and

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{\varphi(n)}}, z^{\varphi(n)}-z^{\star}\right\rangle=0
$$

By continuity of the map $z \mapsto\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)\right], \mathbb{E}\left[\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)\right]\right)$, it follows that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{\varphi(n)}}, z^{\varphi(n)}-z^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& \quad=\left\langle\mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H\left(z^{\infty}, X\right)}{\kappa\left(y^{\infty}\right) \nabla_{y} H\left(z^{\infty}, X\right)}\right]\right], z^{\infty}-z^{\star}\right\rangle=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and, by Lemma 3.2, implies that $z^{\infty}=z^{\star}$. Subsequently, coming back to (A.9), we deduce that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{n}\right)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} D_{G}\left(z^{\varphi(n)}, z^{\star}\right)=0
$$

which clearly implies that the sequence $\left(z^{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$ converges a.s. towards $z^{*}$. Note additionally that taking expectation on both sides of (A.8) and using Lemma 3.2 together with a direct induction argument give

$$
\sup _{n \geq 1} \mathbb{E}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{n}, z^{*}\right)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{*}, z^{0}\right)\right]+m \vee 1 M_{\star}^{2} \sum_{n \geq 1} \gamma_{n}^{2}
$$

The above bound will be useful in order to investigate the convergence rate of $\left(\bar{z}^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$ in the next step.
Step 2: On the convergence rate of $\left(\bar{z}^{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$
We now come back to (A.6) getting

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{k+1}\langle & \mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\rangle \\
\leq & D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{k}\right)-D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{k+1}\right)-\gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\Delta^{k+1}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& +m \vee 1 \gamma_{k+1}^{2} Y_{k+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Summing over $k=0,1, \cdots, n$ the previous inequality and recalling that $D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{n+1}\right) \geq$ 0 , we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}\langle & \mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\rangle \\
& \leq D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{0}\right)-M_{n}+m \vee 1 \sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}^{2} Y_{k+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we introduced the notation

$$
M_{n}:=\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\Delta^{k+1}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\rangle, \quad n \geq 0
$$

Note that since $\left(\Delta^{k}\right)_{k \geq 1}$ is a sequence of $\mathcal{F}$-martingale increments, $\left(M_{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$ is an $\mathcal{F}$-martingale.

Combining the convexity of $h$ with Jensen's inequality, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}\langle & \mathbb{E}\left[\binom{\partial_{\xi} H(z, X)}{\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)}\right]_{\mid z=z^{k}}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\rangle \\
& \geq \sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1} \kappa\left(y^{k}\right)\left\langle\nabla h\left(z^{k}\right), z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\rangle \\
& \geq \sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1} \kappa\left(y^{k}\right)\left(h\left(z^{k}\right)-h\left(z^{\star}\right)\right) \\
& \geq \min _{0 \leq k \leq n} \kappa\left(y^{k}\right)\left(\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}\right)\left(h\left(\bar{z}^{n}\right)-h\left(z^{\star}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (A.11) with (A.12) eventually yields

$$
h\left(\bar{z}^{n}\right)-h\left(z^{\star}\right) \leq \frac{1}{\min _{0 \leq k \leq n} \kappa\left(y^{k}\right)} \frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{0}\right)-M_{n}+m \vee 1 \sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}^{2} Y_{k+1}\right]
$$

Step 3:
To conclude the proof, we provide some uniform controls on the two last terms involved in the right-hand side of the previous upper-bound (A.13). Recall that $\left\{M_{n}:=\sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}\left\langle\Delta^{k+1}, z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\rangle, n \geq 1\right\}$ is an $\mathcal{F}$-martingale. Since

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\Delta^{k+1}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left|\mathcal{F}_{k}\right| \leq d \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\left(\begin{array}{c}
\partial_{\xi} H(z, X) \\
\kappa(y) \nabla_{y} H(z, X)
\end{array}\right)\right\|_{\infty}^{2}\right] \leq d N_{\star}^{2}\right.
$$

we get

$$
\langle M\rangle_{n} \leq d M_{\star}^{2} \sup _{k \geq 0}\left\|z^{k}-z^{\star}\right\|_{2}^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{n} \gamma_{k+1}^{2}
$$

which in turn implies that $\langle M\rangle_{\infty}=\lim _{n}\langle M\rangle_{n}<\infty$ a.s. Hence, $\left(M_{n}\right)_{n \geq 1}$ converges a.s. to $M_{\infty}<\infty$ a.s. Moreover, from (3.8) and (A.10), we deduce
$\sup _{n \geq 0} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|z^{\star}-z^{n}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq 2(m \vee 1) \sup _{n \geq 0} \mathbb{E}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{n}\right)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[D_{G}\left(z^{\star}, z^{0}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{2}(m \vee 1) N_{\star}^{2} \sum_{n \geq 1} \gamma_{n}^{2}<\infty$
so that
$\sup _{n \geq 1} \mathbb{E}\left[M_{n}^{2}\right] \leq \sum_{n \geq 0} \gamma_{n+1}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\Delta^{n+1}\right\|_{2}^{2}\left\|z^{\star}-z^{n}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq d N_{\star}^{2} \sup _{n \geq 0} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|z^{\star}-z^{n}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \sum_{n \geq 0} \gamma_{n+1}^{2}<\infty$.
Hence, $\left(M_{n}\right)_{\geq 1}$ is bounded in $L^{2}(\mathbb{P})$.
To conclude, note that the third term in (A.13) is bounded a.s. and in $L^{1}(\mathbb{P})$ since

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{n \geq 0} \gamma_{n+1}^{2} Y_{k+1}\right] \leq N_{\star}^{2} \sum_{n \geq 0} \gamma_{n+1}^{2}
$$

The proof is now complete.

abstract:
This paper introduces and examines numerical approximation schemes for
computing risk budgeting portfolios associated to positive homogeneous and
sub-additive risk measures. We employ Mirror Descent algorithms to determine
the optimal risk budgeting weights in both deterministic and stochastic
settings, establishing convergence along with an explicit non-asymptotic
quantitative rate for the averaged algorithm. A comprehensive numerical
analysis follows, illustrating our theoretical findings across various risk
measures -- including standard deviation, Expected Shortfall, deviation
measures, and Variantiles -- and comparing the performance with that of the
standard stochastic gradient descent method recently proposed in the
literature.
